Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ethnographic Analysis of Linkages between Rural Land Dispossession, Land Use Change, and Deforestation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award will investigate the human causes and consequences of agricultural expansion with accompanying deforestation. Deforestation's environmental impacts, including soil erosion, increased flooding, desertification, and habitat loss, are well-established. Logging can be a deforestation trigger, but agriculture is its biggest driver. Small-scale farmers cut wood for fuel and clear modest spaces for crops; mechanized, industrial farming and large-scale ranching clear larger tracts. Industrial agriculture has increased food production and reduced local food shortages. But because these large scale operations require access to expensive technologies and farming inputs, the expansion of industrial agriculture has also pushed poor rural farmers off their lands into cities and into the global flow of migrants. This confluence of agriculture, deforestation, urbanization, and migration changes local environments, destabilizes local politics, and impacts migrant receiving countries, including the United States. These processes are well-documented on a global scale, but the local-level micro-processes that set these effects off in the beginning are much more poorly understood. How exactly does mechanized agriculture expand into forested areas? How do smallholders lose control of land? Why do so many end up leaving for urban areas? These are the questions the research funded by this award will address.

The research will be carried out by University of Arizona anthropology doctoral student, Cari Tusing, with the supervision of senior anthropologist Dr. Linda B. Green. Because these processes have already taken place in the United States, where industrial agriculture is now the norm, Tusing will travel to Paraguay where industrial soy farming is just now moving into forested areas, dramatically modifying the landscape and giving Paraguay a deforestation rate that is among the highest in the world. The researcher will concentrate data collection in the region surrounding the Paraguay-Brazil border, where Brazilians are crossing into Paraguay to develop land for large-scale agriculture and ranching in an area where Paraguayan small-scale farmers and Guarani Amerindians practice agroforestry and subsistence agriculture. The researcher will collect data on land titling; class, race, and national identities; and cultural understandings of the relationship between agriculture and deforestation. For this phase of a multi-phase project, the investigator will focus on the Brazilian (also called Brasiguayo) farmers to document their farming practices, strategies employed to obtain land, and social and economic networks. Data will be collected with multiple social science methods including participant observation, interviews, and farm transect walks. Comparable data have already been collected on small-holder farmers and Guarani Amerindians. Cumulatively, the three data sets will produce a fully rounded account of the nature of recent land-use change and its effects on agricultural production, deforestation, local livelihoods, and rural-to-urban migration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One environmental challenge facing the world today is deforestation due to industrial farming. Deforestation causes extreme local impacts like desertification or flooding, and monocropping causes soil exhaustion. In many parts of the world, poor rural people are vulnerable to displacement by industrial farming. As the demand for land rises, poor rural people are often dispossessed. This is caused by many factors, for example, they may lack title; they might be pressured or threatened; they may be offered what seems like a large sum for land that is, in reality, far below market value. If they stay, they often bear brunt of industry, exposed to chemicals that accumulate in land and water. In short, industry-driven deforestation and pesticide use can leave forest people without their forests.

Through the lens of land titling, my research provides insight into factors that influence the local, regional, and global issues of agricultural production, deforestation, and rural-to-urban migration, extending the study of land dispossession in rural areas by incorporating an on-the-ground examination of land use and land tenure strategies by studying both marginalized actors and elites.

While Paraguay may sound like a remote case, anthropologist Eric Wolf contends that the ‘edge’ cases often reveal much about the ‘center.’ Paraguay has one of the world’s highest rates of deforestation, and industrial farming is moving into forested areas, dramatically modifying the landscape and grabbing land. This project contributes to social studies of transnational land grabs across the globe with a Paraguayan case study and dialogues with political ecology, geography, and Latin American Studies.

As industrial agriculture expands into rural areas, it pushes migration toward urban centers. This confluence of agriculture, deforestation, and urbanization changes local environments and destabilizes local politics, and also impacts migration trends on a global scale that directly concerns the United States. My research reveals how local conflicts impacting migration are linked to international dynamics such as industrial agriculture. Understanding complex factors leading people to leave home to migrate allows us to better address US policy toward migrants, as well as US policy toward large farming conglomerates.

Further, this research advances understandings of the bearing of land tenure on the lived experiences of rural people. Fomenting land title for marginalized groups appears to help address the problem of deforestation. Research shows that indigenous people are often effective stewards of forest land. Small-holder farmers who practice agroecology also help to maintain healthy local environments. As land titles make up property regimes, this organizes how people live on, use, and profit from land around the world. My research points out issues with how the property regimes are designed, and how land titling can, ironically, severely impact poor rural people’s ability to retain their land. Communities might break apart over decisions like renting to industrial agriculture or ranchers. This does not mean that titling is a useless endeavor. Rather, practitioners and communities alike must consider titling has multiple and sometimes unexpected outcomes, including further violence and land loss.

The NSF-funded portion of this project focused on elites land use and titling in conjunction with deforestation. By focusing on elites who are the primary land holders, we can understand how they justify their land use and deforestation, while comparing and contrasting land use of indigenous people and small-holder farmers. My major findings stem from 8 months of field work with elite Paraguayans and Brasiguayos who are majority land owners and renters. I found that elites reductively interpreted all relationships to land through the lens of private property. This serves to uphold a property regime to the benefit of elite Paraguayans and foreigners, who then must justify the enormous inequality of land distribution facing poor farmers and indigenous people. By analyzing ethnographic data, I identified an elite narrative moralizing land and labor exploitation. Their interpretation of a ‘moral’ economy links rational, agro-industrial land use to a specific morality of work. The elite narrative narrowly defines work to relations of technical, capitalist production, and racializes other productive relationships to land as backwards, unpatriotic, non-modern, or simply negates that work and labels them as lazy. Thus the pressure on elites created by other claims on land (by small-holder farmers or indigenous people) is resolved through racializing these peoples’ work and production. The ‘rational’, ‘moral’ elite narrative explaining their concentration of private property also spurs deforestation, as technical, industrial farming and ranching require large, deforested fields.

The project brought community partners that previously only worked with indigenous people into dialogue with other rural actors, thus expanding education on land rights, by training 3 local activists and researchers in ethnographic methods. I presented initial results to local social scientists and the general public at a local university and municipality, fomenting the exchange of scholarly ideas. I also carried out academic presentations and participated workshops on this research in the US, Argentina, Chile, and Paraguay.
